{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Coord|37.421731|-122.211275|display=title}} {{Infobox company | name = Kleiner Perkins | logo = File:Kleiner Perkins logo black.svg | logo_size = | logo_padding = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | former_name = Kleiner Perkins | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = [[Private equity]] | genre = | fate = | founded = {{Start date and age|1972}} in [[California]] | founders = [[Eugene Kleiner]], [[Thomas Perkins (businessman)|Tom Perkins]], [[Frank J. Caufield]], [[Brook Byers]] | hq_location = [[Sand Hill Road]] | hq_location_city = [[Menlo Park, California]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | num_locations = | num_locations_year = | area_served = | key_people = | products = [[Investment]]s
[[Venture capital fund]]s | brands = | production = | production_year = | services = | revenue = | revenue_year = | operating_income = | income_year = | net_income = | net_income_year = | aum = | assets = | assets_year = | equity = | equity_year = | owner = | members = | members_year = | num_employees = | num_employees_year = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | website = {{URL|https://www.kleinerperkins.com/}} | footnotes = }} '''Kleiner Perkins,''' formerly '''Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers''' ('''KPCB'''), is an American [[venture capital firm]] headquartered on [[Sand Hill Road]] in [[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]] in [[Silicon Valley]]. Specializing in investments in incubation, early stage and growth companies, since its founding in 1972 the firm has backed entrepreneurs{{cite web |url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=21381 |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |title=Capital Markets: Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers |accessdate=27 July 2011}} in over 850 ventures,{{Citation |year=2017 |title=Companies |publisher= Kleiner Perkins|publication-place= |page= |url= http://www.kpcb.com/companies |accessdate= July 22, 2017}} including [[AOL|America Online]], [[Amazon.com]], [[Compaq]], [[Electronic Arts]], [[JD.com]], [[Square, Inc.|Square]], [[Genentech]], [[Google]], [[Netscape]], [[Sun Microsystems]], Nest, [[Synack]], [[Snap Inc.|Snap]], AppDynamics, and [[Twitter]]. Kleiner Perkins focuses its global investments in practice areas including technology and [[life sciences]]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' and other publications have called it one of the "largest and most established" venture capital firms{{cite news| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2010/01/22/one-of-these-venture-capital-firms-is-not-like-the-other/ | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | title=One Of These Venture Firms Is Not Like The Other | first=Scott | last=Austin | date=2010-01-22}} and ''Dealbook'' named it "one of Silicon Valley’s top venture capital providers."{{cite news| url=http://dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/03/gores-dual-role-in-spotlight-advocate-and-investor/ | work=[[The New York Times]] (Dealbook)| title=Gore's Dual Role in Spotlight: Advocate and Investor | date=3 November 2009}} In addition to its Menlo Park headquarters, the company has offices in [[San Francisco]][http://www.kpcb.com/offices/ Kleiner Perkins Offices at KPCB.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722110239/http://www.kpcb.com/offices/ |date=22 July 2010 }} and [[Shanghai, China]].{{Citation |title=Headquarters |publisher= KPCB China |url=http://www.kpcb.com/china/ |accessdate= May 2, 2017}} == History == {{history of private equity and venture capital}} The firm was formed in 1972 as Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers (KPCB)[http://www.kpcb.com/initiatives/it/ KPCB Information Technology] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603064342/http://www.kpcb.com/initiatives/it/ |date= 3 June 2010 }}{{cite news| url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/05/01/kleiner-perkins-goes-late-on-energy/ | work=[[The New York Times]] | title=Kleiner Perkins Goes Late on Energy | first=Matt | last=Richtel | date=2008-05-01}} on [[Sand Hill Road]] in [[Menlo Park, California]],{{Citation |year=2003 |title=Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers History |publisher=International Directory of Company Histories, Vol. 53. [[St. James Press]]|url= http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/kleiner-perkins-caufield-byers-history/|accessdate= May 17, 2017}} with a focus on seed, early-stage, and growth investments. The firm is named after its four founding partners: [[Eugene Kleiner]], [[Thomas Perkins (businessman)|Tom Perkins]], [[Frank J. Caufield]], and [[Brook Byers]]. Kleiner was a founder of [[Fairchild Semiconductor]], and Perkins was an early [[Hewlett-Packard]] executive. Byers joined in 1977. Located in [[Menlo Park, California]], Kleiner Perkins had access to the growing technology industries in the area. By the early 1970s, there were many [[semiconductor]] companies based in the [[Santa Clara Valley]] as well as early computer firms using their devices and programming and service companies. Venture capital firms suffered a temporary downturn in 1974, when the stock market crashed and investors were naturally wary of this new kind of investment fund. Nevertheless, the firm was still active in this period.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} By 1996, Kleiner Perkins had handed out $880 million in funding to around 260 companies. Beyond the original founders, notable members of the firm have included individuals such as{{cite news |title=Team |url=http://www.kpcb.com/teams |newspaper= |location=KPCB |access-date= May 21, 2017}} [[John Doerr]], {{Cite book | isbn = 0-7351-0141-8 |id={{ISBN|0-395-71133-9}} (hc.); {{ISBN|0 14 025731 4}} (pbk.) | first = Jerry | last = Kaplan | authorlink = Jerry Kaplan | year = 1996 | orig-year = first published by Houghton Mifflin Company 1994 | publisher = [[Penguin Books]] | location = Bridgewater, NJ | title = Startup: A Silicon Valley Adventure | url = https://www.amazon.com/Startup-Silicon-Adventure-Jerry-Kaplan/dp/0735101418/ref=sr_1_1/180-9648880-5248408?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1276474501&sr=1-1 | accessdate = June 13, 2010 | pages = 301–302 | quote = }} [[Vinod Khosla]], and [[Bill Joy]].{{cite news |last=Primack |first= Dan|date=April 16, 2012 |title=Exclusive: Big changes coming to Kleiner Perkins |url=http://fortune.com/2012/04/16/exclusive-big-changes-coming-to-kleiner-perkins/ |newspaper= [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|location= |access-date= May 21, 2017}} [[Colin Powell]] joined as a “strategic” partner in 2005,{{cite news |last= Rivlin|first= Gary|date=July 13, 2005 |title=Colin Powell Joins Venture Capital Firm |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/13/business/colin-powell-joins-venture-capital-firm.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location= |access-date= May 21, 2017}} while [[Al Gore]] joined as partner in 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.kpcb.com/initiatives/greentech/ |title=Greentech Initiative |accessdate=2007-11-13 |publisher=Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116140910/http://www.kpcb.com/initiatives/greentech/ |archivedate=16 November 2007 |df= }}{{cite news|first=Zachary |last=Coile |title = Gore joins Valley's Kleiner Perkins to push green business |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/11/13/BAUCTAV4I.DTL |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle ]]|date= 13 November 2007 |accessdate = 2007-11-13}} as part of a collaboration between Kleiner Perkins and [[Generation Investment Management]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kpcb.com/news/articles/2007_11_12.html |title=Generation Investment Management and Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers Create International Alliance to Accelerate Global Climate Solutions |accessdate=2007-11-13 |date=2007-11-12 |publisher=Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, [[Generation Investment Management]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114144510/http://www.kpcb.com/news/articles/2007_11_12.html |archivedate=14 November 2007 |df= }} [[Mary Meeker]] joined the firm in 2010, and that year Kleiner Perkins expanded its practice to invest in growth stage companies.{{cite news |last=McBride |first=Sarah |date=June 27, 2014 |title=Kleiner Perkins files to raise $1.2 billion in new venture funds |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venture-fundraising-kleiner-idUSKBN0F22M020140628 | work=[[Reuters]] |location= |access-date=June 20, 2017}} The ''New York Times'' has described Kleiner Perkins as “perhaps [[Silicon Valley]]’s most famous venture firm.” The firm was described by ''[[New York Times|Dealbook]]'' in 2009 as "one of Silicon Valley’s top venture capital providers,” and ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' in 2010 called it one of the "largest and most established" venture capital firms. By 2017 it had raised around $10 billion in 20 venture capital funds and four growth funds. In May 2012, [[Ellen Pao]], an employee, sued the firm for [[gender discrimination]] in ''[[Pao v. Kleiner Perkins]]'',{{cite news|last=McBride|first=Sarah|title=Kleiner partner sues firm for discrimination|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/22/kleiner-discrimination-idUSL1E8GMAJS20120522|accessdate=15 June 2012|newspaper=[[Reuters]]|date=22 May 2012}} which the firm has vigorously denied.{{cite news|title=Kleiner Perkins ‘Vigorously Denies’ Ellen Pao’s Gender Discrimination Claims|date=May 22, 2012 |last=Roy |first=Jessica |url=http://betabeat.com/2012/05/kleiner-perkins-sued-for-sexual-harassment-and-gender-discrimination/|accessdate=15 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Observer]] (Betabeat)}} On March 27, 2015, after a month-long trial, the jury found against Pao on all claims.{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/jury-backs-kleiner-perkins-in-sex-bias-case-1427491235 | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | first=Jeff | last=Elder | title=Jury Backs Kleiner Perkins in Sex-Bias Case | date=28 March 2015}} In June 2015, Pao filed an appeal.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/08/11/pao-appeals-trial-costs/|title=Ellen Pao appeals order to pay Kleiner Perkins trial costs|first=Kia|last=Kocalitcheva|publisher=''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]''|date=2015-08-11|accessdate=2015-10-01}} In September 2015, Pao announced she would no longer appeal the jury verdict.{{cite news |last=Elder |first=Jeff |date= September 10, 2015|title=Ellen Pao Won’t Appeal Trial Loss in Case Against Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/ellen-pao-wont-appeal-trial-loss-in-case-against-kleiner-perkins-caufield-byers-1441906196|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |location=New York City |access-date=May 2, 2017}} In September 2018, Kleiner Perkins announced it was spinning out its digital growth team into a new independent firm.https://www.axios.com/kleiner-perkins-is-splitting-up-1536933575-dccd3c28-2900-4ba4-ab23-b8e3e3f89a55.htmlhttps://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/14/technology/mary-meeker-kleiner-perkins.html == Investments == In March 2008 Kleiner Perkins announced the [[iFund]], a $100 million venture capital investment initiative that funds concepts related to the iPhone, and doubled that investment a year later.[http://www.kpcb.com/initiatives/ifund KPCB doubles iFund investment to $200MM] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080310234957/http://www.kpcb.com/initiatives/ifund/ |date=10 March 2008 }} It was reported in April 2008 that Kleiner Perkins was raising funds for a $500 million growth-stage clean-technology fund.{{cite news|first=Alexander |last=Haislip |author2=Dan Primack |title=Kleiner Perkins raising green growth fund |url=http://www.pewnews.com/story.asp?sectioncode=36&storycode=44384 |work=Private Equity Week |publisher= |date=24 April 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501010525/http://www.pewnews.com/story.asp?sectioncode=36&storycode=44384 |archivedate= 1 May 2008 |df= }} In October 2010, the firm launched a $250 million fund called sFund to focus on social startups, with co-investors such as [[Facebook]], [[Zynga]] and [[Amazon.com]].{{cite web | title=The Kleiner Perkins sFund: A $250 mn bet that social is just getting started |first=Michael |last=Arrington| url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/10/21/the-kleiner-perkins-sfund-a-250-million-bet-that-social-is-just-getting-started/ | publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|date=October 21, 2010|accessdate=22 October 2010}} In early 2016, the firm raised $1.4 billion in KP XVII and DGF III.{{cite news |last=Levy |first=Ari |date=May 23, 2016 |title=Kleiner Perkins raising close to $1.3 billion for two funds: Sources |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/05/23/kleiner-perkins-raising-close-to-13-billion-for-two-funds-sources.html |newspaper=CNBC |location= |access-date=May 21, 2017}} The firm has been an early investor in more than 850 technology and [[life sciences]] firms since its founding, including [[Amazon.com]], [[America Online]],{{cite news |last=Clifford |first= Stephanie|date=April 28, 2008 |title=Venture Firm Hires Creative Chief at Electronic Arts |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE7DD153EF93BA15757C0A96E9C8B63 | work=[[The New York Times]] |location=New York City, United States |access-date=May 21, 2017}} [[Brio Technology]], [[Compaq]],{{cite news |last= |first= |date=14 March 1984 |title=Executive Joins Kleiner Perkins |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9903E4DF1339F937A25750C0A962948260 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location= |access-date= May 15, 2017}} [[Electronic Arts]], [[Flextronics]], [[Genentech]], [[Geron Corporation|Geron]],{{cite web |title=SEC Schedule 13G, filed Feb. 17, 1999 |url= http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/DisplayFiling.aspx?TabIndex=2&FilingID=1363847&companyid=11441&ppu=%252fDefault.aspx%253fcompanyid%253d11441%2526amp%253bformtypeID%253d346}} [[Google]], [[Intuit]], [[Lotus Development]], [[LSI Logic]], [[Macromedia]], [[Netscape]], [[Quantum Corporation|Quantum]], [[Segway Inc.|Segway]], [[Sun Microsystems]], [[Synack]],{{cite news |last= Lev-Ram |first=Michal |date=April 24, 2014 |title=For crowdsourced security startup, a carrot and a hack |url=http://fortune.com/2014/04/24/for-crowdsourced-security-startup-a-carrot-and-a-hack/ | work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |location= |access-date=April 30, 2017}} [[Tandem Computers]],{{Citation |year=1992 |title=Tandem Computers - ''International Directory of Company Histories'' Vol. 6 |publisher= [[St. James Press]]|publication-place= |page= |url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/TANDEM-COMPUTERS-INC-Company-History.html |accessdate= }} [[Nebula (company)|Nebula]],{{cite web|last=Morgan|first=Timothy Prickett|title=NASA's former CTO launches Nebula cloud controller |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/07/27/nebula_openstack_cloud_controller/|date=July 27, 2011|publisher=''[[The Register]]''|accessdate=12 March 2013}} and [[The 3DO Company]].{{cite journal|last= |first= |title=75 Power Players|journal=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=11|publisher=[[Imagine Media]]|date=November 1995|pages=66–67|quote=Kleiner, Perkins, {{sic|Coffhil & Beyers}} were one of the initial investors in The 3DO Company, and as a result, they made a lot of money.}} Some current private investments include Newsela,{{cite web|title=Newsela Profile |url=http://www.builtinnyc.com/company/newsela|website=Built in NYC|accessdate=15 March 2017}} [[Align Commerce]],{{cite news|last1=Chernova|first1=Yuliya|title=Kleiner Perkins Makes First Bitcoin Related Deal With Aligh Commerce|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2015/11/17/kleiner-perkins-makes-first-bitcoin-related-deal-with-align-commerce/|accessdate=18 November 2015|publisher=''[[Wall Street Journal]]''|date=17 November 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Shin|first1=Laura|title=Kleiner Perkins Makes First Bitcon Startup Investment With B2B Payments Provider Align Commerce|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/laurashin/2015/11/17/kleiner-perkins-makes-first-bitcoin-startup-investment-with-b2b-payments-provider-align-commerce/|accessdate=18 November 2015|publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=17 November 2015}} [[AlienVault]], Ionic Security, [[AirBnB]], [[DJI (company)|DJI]], [[Armo]], [[Spotify]], Handshake, Ring, Clean Power Finance, [[Coursera]], Datameer,{{cite news |last= Finley|first= Klint|date=September 25, 2012 |title=Analytics Company Datameer Raises $6 Million From Redpoint Ventures and Kleiner Perkins|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/09/25/analytics-company-datameer-raises-6-million-from-redpoint-ventures-and-kleiner-perkins/ |newspaper=[[TechCrunch]] |location= |access-date= May 17, 2017}} Shape Security,{{cite web|last1=Primack|first1=Dan|title=Deals of the day: Shape Security raises $40 million|url=http://fortune.com/2014/02/25/deals-of-the-day-shape-security-raises-40-million/|website=Fortune|publisher=''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]''|accessdate=14 May 2015}} SimpliVity, Leanplum, and [[Uber (company)|Uber]]. Kleiner Perkins paid $5 million in 1994 for around 25% of [[Netscape]] and profited from Netscape's [[initial public offering|IPO]].{{cite news|last1=Corcoran|first1=Elizabeth|title=Venture Capital Firm Kleiner Perkins Has Long Nurtured Internet Enterprises|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/washtech/longterm/techinvest/stories/kleiner.htm|accessdate=September 2, 2014|publisher=‘’[[Washington Post]]’’|date=October 13, 1996}} Its investment of $8 million in [[Cerent]] was worth around $2 billion{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} when the optical equipment maker was sold to [[Cisco Systems]] for $6.9 billion in August 1999.[http://news.cnet.com/Cisco-buys-Cerent,-Monterey-Networks/2100-1033_3-230304.html Cisco buys Cerent, Monterey Networks] - [[CNET]] (August 1999) In 1999, Kleiner Perkins and [[Sequoia Capital]] paid $24 million for 20% of [[Google]]—as of February 2018 Google's [[market capitalization]] stood at about $700 billion.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} As initial investors in Amazon.com Kleiner Perkins scored returns in excess of $1 billion{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} on an $8 million investment.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=2004 |title=How John Doerr, the old prospector, finally struck Google |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/how-john-doerr-the-old-prospector-finally-struck-google/ |newspaper=[[CNET]] |location= |access-date= May 17, 2017}} Recent investments include [[AppDynamics]], [[ArcSight]], [[Autotrader.com]], [[Foundation Medicine]], [[Flexus]], [[Lifelock]], [[JD.com]], [[MyFitnessPal]], [[FireEye]] ([[Mandiant]]), [[Nest]], [[Snap (company)|Snap]], [[Square, Inc.|Square]], Tesoara, and [[Twitter]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.kpcb.com/portfolio/ |title=KPCB Portfolio Companies |access-date=28 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301114551/http://www.kpcb.com/portfolio |archive-date=1 March 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Kleiner Perkins funds [[Proterra, Inc.|Proterra Inc]]., an automotive company.{{Cite news|url=https://www.recode.net/2018/5/24/17390640/proterra-electric-bus-fundraising-100-million|title=The electric bus company Proterra is worth up to $840 million after raising new money|work=Recode|access-date=2018-06-04}} ==Key partners== {{see also|Category:Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers people}} The firm currently has nine general partners managing the company:{{cite news |title=Team |url=http://www.kpcb.com/teams |newspaper= |location=KPCB |access-date=September 8, 2017}} * [[John Doerr]] ''(chairman)'' * [[Eric Feng]] * Ilya Fushman * [[Mamoon Hamid]] * Wen Hsieh * Noah Knauf * [[Mary Meeker]] * Mood Rowghani * Ted Schlein * Beth Seidenberg ==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} * [[List of venture capital firms]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [https://www.kleinerperkins.com/ www.kleinerperkins.com] {{Private equity and venture capital}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers}} [[Category:Companies based in Menlo Park, California]] [[Category:Financial services companies established in 1972]] [[Category:Venture capital firms of the United States]] [[Category:1972 establishments in California]] [[Category:Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers| ]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]]

{{Orphan|date=May 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Lou Capozzi | image = LOUIS CAPOZZI.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | nationality = United States | education = BS in marketing and journalism
[[MBA]] in finance | alma_mater = [[New York University]]
Bernard Baruch Graduate School of Business | occupation = Pro tem instructor, University of Oregon | years_active = 1968–present | salary = | networth = | spouse = | children = | religion = | signature = }} '''Louis Capozzi '''currently teaches in the master's degree program in Strategic Communication at the University of Oregon School of Journalism and Communication in Portland, Oregon. ==Career== Capozzi has a broad background in public relations and corporate communications, with more than 40 years' experience in both major public relations firms and with large [[multinational corporations]].{{cite news|url=http://www.prweek.com/article/204173 |title=PROFILE: From the Bronx to the board – Lou Capozzi, chairman/CEO, Manning Selvage & Lee |publisher=PRWeek |first=Gidon |last=Freeman |date= March 5, 2004}} He started his career in public relations as a financial writer, writing and producing dozens of corporate [[annual reports]], acting as a [[speechwriter]] for CEOs and handling financial and investor communications and [[crisis management]] for dozens of companies from small, newly listed businesses to [[Fortune 50]] global corporations. Capozzi is often interviewed and featured{{cite news|url= http://www.holmesreport.com/opinion-info/5275/Is-This-the-Start-of-a-Beautiful-Friendship-Between-PR-and-Consulting.aspx |title=Is This the Start of a Beautiful Friendship Between PR and Consulting? |publisher=The Holmes Report |first=Paul |last=Holmes |date=September 17, 2006}} in the global communications and business media, frequently contributes to communications industry [[publications]],{{cite web|url=http://www.prconversations.com/index.php/2006/10/lou-capozzi-pr-people-are-too-siloed-should-take-a-broader-view-and-need-to-get-better-at-managing-advertising/ |title=Lou Capozzi- PR people are too siloed, should take a broader view and need to get better at managing advertising! |publisher=PR Conversations |first=Toni Muzi |last=Falconi |date= October 15, 2006}}{{cite web|url= http://blog.muckrack.com/post/28124776715/listening-to-journalists-on-twitter |title= Listening to journalists on Twitter |publisher=The Muck Rack Blog |date= July 27, 2012}} and acts a spokesman for the industry in global media and as a speaker at industry events.{{cite news|url=http://www.holmesreport.com/news-info/5168/Industry-Leaders-to-Participate-in-PRSA-NY-Mentioring-Program.aspx |title= Leaders to Participate in PRSA NY Mentoring Program |publisher=The Holmes Report |first=Paul |last=Holmes |date= July 31, 2006}}{{cite web|url= http://www.genesisbm.in/the-icco-summit/ |title= The ICCO Summit |publisher=Genesis Burson-Marsteller |date= October 17, 2011}} ===Hill & Knowlton=== He began his public relations career at [[Hill & Knowlton]] in 1968 as an intern and the firm's first graduate trainee.{{cite news|url=http://www.prweek.com/article/99702/profile-lou-capozzi-manning-selvage-lee---ms-l-heralds-new-dawn-manning-selvage-lee-rsquos-new-ceo-expects-focus-clients-creativity |title=Profile: Lou Capozzi, Manning Selvage and Lee – MS&L heralds a new dawn/Manning Selvage and Lee’s new CEO expects to focus on clients and creativity. |publisher=PRWeek |first=Jemimah |last=Bailey |date= June 27, 1997}} ===AutEx, Inc.=== Capozzi was [[director of Communications]] and Investor Relations at AutEx, Inc., operators of the Block Trading Information System for financial institutions and brokers. ===Ketchum=== He joined [[Ketchum Inc.]] in public relations as an account supervisor in the firm's [[Pittsburgh]] headquarters and later served as managing director of the New York office. ===Aetna Life & Casualty=== Capozzi was [[chief communications officer]] of [[Aetna]] Life & Casualty,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/01/30/business/advertising-new-goal-for-aetna-campaign.html |title=Advertising; New Goal For Aetna Campaign |publisher=The New York Times |first=Philip |last=Dougherty |date= January 30, 1986}} at that time the nation's largest [[public company|publicly owned]] [[insurance company]]. He managed a 150-person corporate communications department with a budget of more than $80 million, and was responsible for advertising, corporate public relations, financial and shareholder communications, [[marketing communications]], employee communications and investor relations support. ===MSL Group=== He was chairman of the MSL Group,{{cite news|url=http://www.prweekus.com/pages/login.aspx?returl=/publicis-creates-umbrella-pr-group-places-capozzi-on-top/article/52052/&pagetypeid=28&articleid=52052&accesslevel=2&expireddays=0&accessAndPrice=0 |title=Publicis creates umbrella PR group, places Capozzi on top |publisher=PRWeek US |first=Hamilton |last=Nolan |date= April 11, 2005}} now the world's fourth-largest public relations firm, from 1999 until his retirement at the end of 2008. There he managed operations in more than 30 cities around the world. The firm is part of [[Publicis Groupe]],{{cite news|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=1799116&ticker=PUB:FP |title=Publicis Groupe |publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek |date=February 20, 2014}} the world's 3rd-largest communications group. ==Philanthropy and volunteerism== ===In the public relations profession=== Capozzi was awarded the PRSA Gold Anvil for lifetime achievement in 2017. The Gold Anvil is the society's highest individual Award, presented to a public relations practitioner whose accomplishments have made a major contribution to the profession.{{cite web|url=https://www.prsa.org/award/individual-award-gold-anvil-award/|title=Gold Anvil Award - Public Relations Society of America|website=PRSA.org|access-date=January 25, 2018}} He served for three years as president of the [[PRSA Foundation]].{{cite news|url=http://www.prweekus.com/pages/login.aspx?returl=/prsa-aims-at-diverse-talent-development/article/267603/&pagetypeid=28&articleid=267603&accesslevel=2&expireddays=0&accessAndPrice=0 |title=PRSA aims at diverse talent development |publisher=PRWeek US |first=Lou |last=Capozzi |date=November 9, 2012}} In that role, he worked to drive [[Multiculturalism|diversity]] in the public relations profession. The foundation partners with universities and other professional and academic organizations to build programs to attract more African American and [[Hispanic]] students to careers in PR, and to make them better prepared to contribute to the profession, and to society, when they arrive. He is a member of the Arthur Page Society, a former chairman of the Council of Public Relations Firms{{cite news|url=http://www.prweekus.com/pages/login.aspx?returl=/editorial-the-council-of-pr-firms-value-to-the-industry-should-rise-under-chairmanship-of-capozzi/article/48523/&pagetypeid=28&articleid=48523&accesslevel=2&expireddays=0&accessAndPrice=0 |title=EDITORIAL: The Council of PR Firms' value to the industry should rise under chairmanship of Capozzi |publisher=PRWeek US |first=Julia |last=Hood |date=January 5, 2004}} and the International Communications Consultants Organisation,{{cite news|url=http://www.prweekus.com/pages/login.aspx?returl=/capozzi-to-head-icco/article/55763/&pagetypeid=28&articleid=55763&accesslevel=2&expireddays=0&accessAndPrice=0 |title=Capozzi to head ICCO |publisher=PRWeek US |first=Hamilton |last=Nolan |date=October 5, 2006}} as well as an accredited member of the [[Public Relations Society of America]] and a member of its College of Fellows. ===In the community=== Capozzi serves on the board of Bend 2030, a non-profit working on affordable housing, transportation and livability in Bend, Oregon. He formerly served on the board of the Central Oregon Intergovernmental Council (COIC), focusing on public transit. He has been active in several environmental groups, serving on the board of American Rivers for ten years and on the board of the [[National Parks of New York Harbor Conservancy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nyharborparks.org/conservancy/bio-louis-capozzi.html |title=Board of Directors, Louis Capozzi |publisher=The National Parks of New York Harbor Conservancy}} He also served on the New York advisory board of the National Parks Conservation Association, and acted as a marketing advisor to the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]]. ==Personal life== Capozzi grew up near [[Trenton, New Jersey]]. He attended [[New York University Stern School of Business]],{{cite web|url=http://sternalumni.nyu.edu/s/1068/GroupBus/index.aspx?sid=1068&gid=2&pgid=252&cid=3404&ecid=3404&ciid=18384&crid=0 |title=Lou Capozzi, BS '69 |publisher=NYU Stern}} where he graduated with a degree in marketing and journalism. He also earned an [[MBA]] from the Bernard Baruch School of Business at [[City College of New York]]. He and his wife, Betty, were married in 1969 and live in Bend, Oregon. Their oldest son, Matt, works as a product designer and lives in Bend, Oregon with his wife, Leigh and their two daughters. His younger son, Joe, is married to Amanda Lisboa and is the executive chef at the Bloom Street Hospitality Group, which includes The East Pole, Eastfields, Cafe Americano and Pizza Beach restaurants in New York City. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.prsafoundation.org/ PRSA Foundation official website] * [http://www.nyu.edu/ New York University official website] * [http://www.nyharborparks.org/ New York Harbor Parks official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Capozzi, Louis}} [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:American marketing people]] [[Category:American public relations people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Trenton, New Jersey]] [[Category:City College of New York alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:New York University faculty]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

page.title: Louis Pierre Ancillon de la Sablonnière

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
In 1745 '''Louis Pierre Ancillon de la Sablonnière''' established the Pechelbronn [[bitumen]] mine at [[Merkwiller-Pechelbronn]], [[Bas-Rhin]], [[Alsace]].
He was an interpreter with the [[France|French]] ambassador to [[Switzerland]], then the General Treasurer of the Ligues Suisses and [[Grisons]].
He learned of Jean Theophile Hoeffel's 1734 thesis "Historia Balsami Mineralis Alsatici sev Petrolei Vallis Sancti Lamperti", which described bitumen springs near [[Lampertsloch]]. The farm was later called [[BächelBrunn]]/[[Baechel-Brunn]] for a "little brown stream" or "Baechelbronner" in 1768 when purchased by the LeBel family.<ref>McCosh, Frederick William James, ''Boussingault'' D. Reidel Publishing, New York, 1984, {{ISBN|90-277-1682-X}}</ref>
Along with [[Jean d’Amascéne Eyrénis]], the son of physician [[Eyrini d'Eyrinis]], the developer of the [[La Presta]] [[asphalt]] mine of [[Val de Travers]], [[Neuchâtel]], [[Switzerland]], he obtained permission to start searches around the spring. He created the first oil company in 1740, putting 40 shares on the market.<ref>[http://www.musee-du-petrole.com/site%20anglais/page%205.htm French Museum of Petroleum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027105704/http://musee-du-petrole.com/site%20anglais/page%205.htm |date=2007-10-27 }}</ref><ref>[http://pot-pourri.fltr.ucl.ac.be/itinera/actualites/rhadinace.txt (in French)]</ref><ref>[http://www.swisspassions.com/en/canton-de-neuchatel/decouverte-et-curiosites/mines-dasphalte-de-la-presta-sur-les-pas-des-chercheurs-dor.html de la Presta Asphalt Mines]</ref><ref>[http://www.ville-ge.ch/mhng/page1/bal-05-23.htm Mines d’asphalte du Val-de-Travers (Neuchâtel)]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * [http://www.wabweb.net/history/oel/galizien.htm Am Beginn des Erdölzeitalters] {{de icon}} * [http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=5627813 Otto, C.J. and Toth, J. ''Hydrogeological controls and indicators for oil deposits in rift grabens - An example from the Upper Rhine graben, France'' (abstract)] * Scheld, Alfred: Erdöl im Elsass — Die Anfänge der Ölquellen von Pechelbronn, Ubstadt 2012
{{France-business-bio-stub}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ancillon de la Sablonniere}} [[Category:1745 in France]] [[Category:Asphalt]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:Petroleum products]] [[Category:18th-century French people]] [[Category:Year of death missing]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Politician | image = | name = Maria Borelius | office = [[Minister for Foreign Trade (Sweden)|Minister for Foreign Trade]] | term_start = 6 October 2006 | term_end = 14 October 2006 | predecessor = [[Thomas Östros]] | successor = [[Sten Tolgfors]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|7|6|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Täby]], [[Stockholm County]] | alma_mater = [[Lund University]]
[[New York University]] | party = [[Moderate Party]] | occupation = [[Journalist]], [[entrepreneur]] }} '''Maria Sigrid Astrid Borelius''' is a Swedish born former [[Minister for Foreign Trade (Sweden)|Minister for Foreign Trade]], [[Science journalist]] and [[entrepreneur]], working as advisor to global companies, academies and institutions. Maria is a member of the advisory council of [[Open Europe]], a European think tank with offices in London, Brussels and Berlin promoting ideas for economic and political reform of the European Union. Maria is also a Partner with Living Waters, a [[London]]-based consultancy focusing on CSR, public affairs and developing fundraising strategies. She is an advisor to the [[Karolinska Institute]], which awards the Nobel prize in medicine, and to [[Lund University]] and works as a columnist with the Swedish business daily, [[Dagens Industri]], mainly covering areas of Entrepreneurship, Science, research, globalization and politics. == Education and career == Between 2007 and 2012 Maria Borelius was the Vice Chairman and CEO of Hand in hand International, a UK based charity, working with partnering organisations in the developing world to promote enterprise and job-creation among marginalized women in the bottom billion. During these years the organisations in India, South-Africa, Afghanistan and India grew from 150,000 women in programs, to over 1 million women, with an international fundraising organization being created with UN partnership, and donors among businesses, private individuals and bilateral institutions. Maria Borelius has been active on several boards of listed companies on the Swedish stock exchange, with a focus on technology companies such as Active Biotech, Sweco and [[Telelogic]], and within academia, such as the Swedish National Science board. In 2006 stood for Election for the [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Moderate Party]], on an agenda of promoting entrepreneurship and strengthening schools and universities. Maria Borelius was elected a Member of Parliament from the [[Stockholm County]], and became [[Minister for Foreign Trade (Sweden)|Minister for Foreign Trade]] in the centre-right government that was formed after the election. Within a few weeks two ministers had resigned, and Borelius was one of them. She admitted that she during the 1990s, when her four children were small, had used child-care without reporting to the tax authorities and paying the full 32% social fees, and in the media frenzy that followed, resigned. The [[Swedish Government]] has since then changed the system by which private child care is partly paid through the so-called “RUT” reforms. Together with TV-entrepreneur Annie Wegelius, she started the digital TV-channel and learning portal K-World. Before this Maria Borelius was active as science [[journalist]], and editor for the evening news “Rapport” on [[Sveriges Television|Swedish national public TV]], and the face of the science program NOVA for many years. She produced numerous TV-programs on popular science, such as “To give birth” which got record audiences. She has written several books on popular medicine, such as “Sedan du fött”, translated into German, Norwegian and Danish, and “Motboken” with Marie Bloom. In 2013 Maria joined the advisory council of [[Open Europe]]. Maria Borelius has lived in Great Britain since 2000, is married to Greger Larson, and has four children born 1990, 1992, 1993 and 1995. == Education == * New York University 1986 (Master of Science Reporting) * Lund University 1984 (Fil.kand in Biology, mathematics and physics) == Awards == * 2001 The honorary “Hierta” scholarship from the Swedish Journalist Association. * 1994 Great Journalist prize from the Swedish Cancerfund. * 1984 Scholarship Swedish Science Association. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.openeurope.org.uk/Page/Board/en/LIVE Maria Borelius] at the [[Open Europe]] website * [http://www.riksdagen.se/webbnav/index.aspx?nid=1111&iid=0388849444310 Maria Borelius] at the [[Parliament of Sweden|Riksdag]] website {{sv icon}} * [http://www.moderaterna.net/politiker/politiker_visa.asp?id=364 Maria Borelius]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} at the [[Moderate Party]] website {{sv icon}} * [http://www.mariaborelius.se/ Maria Borelius] personal website {{sv icon}} (Shut down as of October 23, 2006) {{s-start}} {{succession box|before=[[Thomas Östros]]|title=[[Minister for Foreign Trade (Sweden)|Minister for Foreign Trade]]|years=2006|after= [[Sten Tolgfors]] }} {{s-end}} {{Cabinet of Fredrik Reinfeldt}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Borelius, Maria}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Täby Municipality]] [[Category:Swedish journalists]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Moderate Party politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Riksdag 2006–10]] [[Category:Swedish Ministers for Trade]] [[Category:Women members of the Riksdag]] [[Category:Swedish women in business]] [[Category:Women government ministers of Sweden]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]]

Finlay}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox rugby biography | name = Mark Finlay | honorific_suffix = | image = | caption = | nickname = | birth_name = Mark Clayton Finlay | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|05|10|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Palmerston North]], New Zealand | death_place = | death_date = | ru_position = [[Rugby union positions#Full-back|Fullback]] | height = {{convert|1.83|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|89|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | allblackid = 272 | allblackno = 856 | ru_nationalteam = {{ru|New Zealand|noflag=1}} | ru_nationalcaps = 0 | ru_nationalpoints = (0) | ru_nationalyears = 1984 | ru_province = [[Manawatu Rugby Union|Manawatu]]
{{nowrap|[[North Harbour Rugby Union|North Harbour]]}} | ru_provinceyears = 1981–86
1988 | ru_provincecaps = 71
13 | ru_provincepoints = (511) | ru_proclubs = [[Rugby Viadana|Viadana]]
[[Fukuoka Sanix Blues|Sanix]] | ru_clubyears = | ru_clubcaps = | ru_clubpoints = | occupation = Early childhood education centre owner{{cite news | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10805104 | title=Childcare a paying proposition | date=11 May 2012 | work=New Zealand Herald | accessdate=24 July 2014 | first=Nick | last=Smith }} | family = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | school = [[Palmerston North Boys' High School]] | university = }} '''Mark Clayton Finlay''' (born 10 May 1963) is a former New Zealand [[rugby union]] player. He was educated at [[Palmerston North Boys' High School]], where he was a member of the 1st XV between 1979 and 1981. A [[Rugby union positions#Full-back|fullback]], Finlay represented [[Manawatu Rugby Union|Manawatu]] and [[North Harbour Rugby Union|North Harbour]] at a provincial level, and was a member of the New Zealand national side, the [[All Blacks]], in 1984. He played two matches for the All Blacks where he scored a total of 18 points (2 tries, 5 conversions), but made no test appearances.{{Cite book|title = The Encyclopedia Of New Zealand Rugby|last = Chester|first = Rod|publisher = Moa Publications|year = 1987|isbn = 0-908570-16-3|location = Auckland, New Zealand|pages = 61|last2 = McMillan|first2 = Neville|last3 = Palenski|first3 = Ron}}{{cite web| url = http://stats.allblacks.com/asp/Profile.asp?ABID=272 |title = Mark Finlay | last = Knight | first = Lindsay | publisher = New Zealand Rugby Union | accessdate = 24 July 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Portal|Rugby union}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Finlay, Mark}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Rugby union players from Palmerston North]] [[Category:People educated at Palmerston North Boys' High School]] [[Category:New Zealand rugby union players]] [[Category:New Zealand international rugby union players]] [[Category:Manawatu rugby union players]] [[Category:North Harbour rugby union players]] [[Category:Rugby union fullbacks]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriate rugby union players]] [[Category:Expatriate rugby union players in Italy]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriates in Italy]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriates in Japan]] [[Category:Expatriate rugby union players in Japan]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] {{NewZealand-rugbyunion-bio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Use South African English|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Matthew Buckland | image = Matthew buckland destiny2.jpg | caption = Matthew Buckland | birth_name = Matthew James Buckland | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1974|8|22}} | birth_place = [[South Africa]] | education = [[Rhodes University]] | occupation = Internet entrepreneur | boards = [[Silicon Cape Initiative]]
[[Creative Commons]]
[http://www.iabsa.net OPA/DMMA/iAB]
[[Cognition]] | title = Founder and MD of [[Creative Spark]] |residence = [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]] | term = 2010 – Present |awards = [http://issuu.com/fastcompanysa/docs/fc_july_2015_issue_8_ Selected Fast Company Magazine's Most Creative People in Business] (2015), [http://www.bizcommunity.com/Event/196/11/32131.html Destiny Magazine: Power of 40: 40 entrepreneurs under 40 (2011)], Top 100 “South Africa’s most influential media and advertising people” by The Annual (2009) | website = [http://www.creativespark.co.za Company website]
[http://www.memeburn.com Memeburn.com/Burn Media]
[http://www.matthewbuckland.com Personal weblog] | father = [[Andrew Buckland]] }} '''Matthew Buckland''' is a South African [[Internet entrepreneur]] and businessman who founded and exited[http://www.marklives.com/2018/04/buckland-exits-creative-spark-mc-saatchi-group/''Buckland exits Creative Spark, M&C Saatchi Group''] digital agency and publisher Creative Spark, acquired in 2015 by UK firm ''M&C Saatchi PLC'' ({{LSE|SAA}}), the holding group of [[M&C Saatchi]].[http://www.fin24.com/Tech/News/mc-saatchi-acquires-sas-creative-spark-20151127''M&C Saatchi acquires SA’s Creative Spark (Fin24.com)''][http://www.itweb.co.za/?id=148141:Saatchi-acquires-Memeburn-publisher''Saatchi acquires Memeburn publisher (ItWeb)''][http://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/companies-and-deals/creative-spark-sold-to-mc-saatchi/''Creative Spark sold to M&C Saatchi (Moneyweb)''][http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/16/137846.html''BREAKING: Creative Spark acquired by M&C Saatchi PLC (Bizcommunity.com)''][http://www.marklives.com/2015/11/interview-matthew-buckland-on-mc-saatchicreative-spark-deal/''Interview: Matthew Buckland on M&C Saatchi/Creative Spark deal (Marklives)''][http://www.htxt.co.za/2015/11/27/mc-saatchi-acquires-majority-stake-in-digital-agency-creative-spark/''M&C SAATCHI ACQUIRES MAJORITY STAKE IN DIGITAL AGENCY CREATIVE SPARK (HTXT)''][http://mcsaatchi.com/news/2015/mc-saatchi-acquires-creative-spark-south-africa''M&C Saatchi Acquires Creative Spark in South Africa (M&C Saatchi)''] Buckland is also the founder of Burn Media, a suite of technology publishing brands which includes [[Memeburn]], Ventureburn.com, Gearburn.com and others. Buckland previously headed the online division of the ''[[Mail & Guardian]]'', thereafter he started 20fourlabs at [[Naspers]]' news24.com,{{Cite news|url=http://www.itweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=10034|title=Matthew on the move|last=Waal|first=Mandy de|work=ITWeb Technology News|access-date=2018-01-11}}{{Cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2009-06-12-300-young-south-africans-technology-continued|title=300 Young South Africans: Technology (Part 2)|last=Reporter|first=Staff|work=The M&G Online|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://mybroadband.co.za/news/business/17575-sa-online-professionals-do-their-own-thing.html|title=SA online professionals do their own thing|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en-US}} the largest South African online news publisher, owned by [[Naspers]].[http://mybroadband.co.za/news/internet/127946-south-africas-biggest-websites-3.html''South Africa’s biggest websites''] While at the ''Mail & Guardian'' Buckland founded [[Thought Leader]]. In 2015 he was selected as a "Master of Digital", sitting down with actor [[Idris Elba]] for a "Q&A Session".[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CH5Zg6T4miY''The Oude Meester Tour, Day 2 – Cape Town''][http://entertainment.iafrica.com/news/971390.html''Idris Elba tours SA for Oude Meester''] Buckland lives in Cape Town with his wife and two daughters. == Early life == Buckland studied journalism at [[Rhodes University]] in the Eastern Cape, South Africa.[http://www.poynter.org/author/mattattakk/ Matthew Buckland, Poynter.(accessed 16 January 2012)] He worked in London for the BBC's then-commercial web arm, beeb.com as a developer, and then a web development producer.{{Cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/SciTech/Tech4Africa/Speakers/Matthew-Buckland-20100803|title=BIO: Matthew Buckland|work=News24|access-date=2018-01-11}} He then later worked as the Internet editor for prime-time TV show, [[Carte Blanche (TV series)|Carte Blanche]], before becoming Managing Director of [[Mail & Guardian]]'s online division. He is the eldest son of [[Andrew Buckland]] and [[Janet Buckland]], a prominent South African acting family.[http://www.bdlive.co.za/articles/2010/12/07/on-the-stage---andrew-buckland''On the stage - ANDREW BUCKLAND, BDFM, 2010''][http://www.iol.co.za/tonight/news/local/buckland-s-got-a-play-date-with-obsession-1.1836759#.VlsMoHYrJZk''Buckland's got a play date with obsession, IOL, 2015''][https://www.capetown.gov.za/en/smartcape/Peopleofnote/pages/smartcapestd.aspx?pid=701''People of note - Women of Inspiration - Community Buckland Janet''][http://mg.co.za/article/2010-06-14-200-young-south-africans-arts-and-culture''200 Young South Africans: Arts and Culture''] == Entrepreneurship == In 2010 Buckland founded Creative Spark[http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/16/45272.html''Matthew Buckland to pursue creative spark'] and Burn Media, which he funded himself after being unable to raise venture capital for it.{{Cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/multimedia/2015-01-27-extraordinary-life-elon-musk|title=Extraordinary life: Elon Musk|website=The M&G Online|language=en|access-date=2018-01-11}} Five years later, in 2015, he sold a majority share in his company to the FTSE-listed agency, [[M&C Saatchi]].[http://memeburn.com/2015/11/breaking-mc-saatchi-plc-acquires-independent-digital-player-creative-spark/''Breaking: M&C Saatchi PLC acquires independent digital player Creative Spark''] The deal included the sale of both the digital agency and the publishing arm, which owns titles such as [[Memeburn]] and Ventureburn.[http://www.techcentral.co.za/creative-spark-sold-to-mc-saatchi/61639/''Creative Spark sold to M&C Saatchi''] He later retook control of the publishing arm when exiting his former company in 2018.[http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/23/178048.html''Burn Media to embark on aggressive growth after deal to go solo - Buckland''] [http://www.ventureburn.com Ventureburn] is a site that reports on the startup, entrepreneur and investor ecosystems in South Africa, Kenya and Nigeria. He was the Master of Ceremonies{{Cite web|url=http://matthewbuckland.com/?p=1024|title=Enter the Silicon Cape {{!}} Matthew Buckland|website=matthewbuckland.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-11}} at the [[Silicon Cape Initiative]] launch event and was elected to its inaugural board. The [[Silicon Cape Initiative]] is a South African-based organization which aims to turn the Western Cape into a high-tech startup hub. Buckland credits this organisation for inspiring him to move out of the corporate world into entrepreneurship.[http://ventureburn.com/2013/09/the-unwavering-persistence-of-entrepreneurs/''The Unwavering Persistence of Entrepreneurs''] In 2012 Buckland was recognised in the Power of 40: 40 Entrepreneurs Under 40 "Doing Interesting Things"{{Cite news|url=http://www.destinyconnect.com/2012/10/12/valuable-lessons-from-a-chicken-entrepreneur-2012-10-12/|title=Valuable lessons from a "chicken" entrepreneur {{!}} DESTINY Magazine|date=2012-10-12|work=DESTINY Magazine|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en-GB}} In 2013 and 2014 he was a member of the Cape Town chapter of [[Entrepreneurs Organisation]].[http://ventureburn.com/2013/09/the-unwavering-persistence-of-entrepreneurs/''Ventureburn.com''][http://blog.eonetwork.org/tag/matthew-buckland/''High Octane, EO Blog''] == Awards == Buckland’s industry accolades include: * [http://issuu.com/fastcompanysa/docs/fc_july_2015_issue_8_ Selected in Fast Company Magazine's Most Creative People in Business, 2015] * [http://entertainment.iafrica.com/news/971390.html Selected as an "Oude Meeste Master of digital", sitting down for an onscreen discussion with well-known actor Idris Elba, 2015] * [http://socialmediaweek.org/johannesburg/events/ventureburn-startup-battle-powered-ford/ Startup judge/Dragon at Social Media Week: Johannesburg] * [https://thenextweb.com/africa/2012/09/08/pashash-wins-startup-world-cape-town/ NextWeb Startup World - Cape Town - Startup Judge] * Standard Bank Sikuvile journalism awards - Judge * [http://www.bizcommunity.com/Event/196/11/32131.html Listed in Destiny Magazine: Power of 40: 40 entrepreneurs under 40 doing interesting things] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k_gXq_SYWAc Selected for the Old Mutual "Do Great Things" Entrepreneur guide] * [http://www.itweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=28788 Afridoctor app wins Nokia's Africa-wide innovators competition (Prize of US$80 000)] * Named in top 100 of "South Africa's most influential media and advertising people" by The Annual * [http://mg.co.za/article/2009-06-12-300-young-south-africans-technology-continued Named as one of "300 Young South Africans you should take out to lunch" by the Mail & Guardian Newspaper] * [http://www.mediaupdate.co.za/media/20756/ten-of-the-best-with-matthew-buckland Named an upcoming New Media "Mogul" by FHM magazine & nominated for the 2009 Men's Health "Best Man" awards] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.matthewbuckland.com Matthew Buckland’s personal weblog] * [http://www.creativespark.co.za Creative Spark’s official web site] * [http://www.memeburn.com Memeburn] * [http://www.ventureburn.com Ventureburn] * [http://www.gearburn.com Gearburn] * [http://weetracker.com Weetracker] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Buckland, Matthew}} [[Category:South African businesspeople]] [[Category:1974 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Rhodes University alumni]] [[Category:Technology company founders]] [[Category:South African chief executives]] [[Category:Chief executives in the technology industry]] [[Category:South African company founders]] [[Category:South African journalists]]

Municipally owned corporations are [[corporations]] owned by [[municipalities]]. They are typically "organisations with independent corporate status, managed by an [[executive board]] appointed primarily by [[local government]] officials, and with majority public ownership."<ref name=Voornetal>{{cite web|last=Voorn, Bart, Marieke L. Van Genugten, and Sandra Van Thiel (2017)|title=The efficiency and effectiveness of municipally owned corporations: A systematic review|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03003930.2017.1319360|publisher=Local Government Studies, 43(5): 820-841.}}</ref> Some municipally owned corporations rely on revenue from [[user fees]], distinguishing them from [[Government agency|agencies]] and [[special districts]] funded through [[taxation]].<ref name=TavaresCamoes>{{cite web|last=Tavares, Antonio F., and Pedro J. Camões (2007)|title=Local service delivery choices in Portugal: A political transaction costs network|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03003930701417544|publisher=Local Government Studies, 33(4): 535-553.}}</ref> Municipally owned corporations may also differ from local bureaucracies in funding, transaction costs, financial scrutiny, labour rights, permission to operate outside their jurisdiction, and, under some circumstances, in rights to make profits and risk of bankruptcy.<ref name=BelFageda10>{{cite web|last=Bel, Germa, and Xavier Fageda (2010)|title=Partial Privatization in Local Service Delivery: An Empirical Analysis of the Choice of Mixed Firms|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03003930903435856|publisher=Local Government Studies, 36(1): 129-149.}}</ref>
The causes and effects of municipally owned corporations are posited to be different from those of [[state-owned enterprises]]. [[Corporatization]] may be more utilised locally than nationally a way to allow hybrid or flexible forms of public service delivery such as [[public-private partnerships]] and [[inter-municipal cooperation]]. It also allows charging user fees.<ref name=TavaresCamoes /> Effects can be different because of lower regulator expertise, lower contracting capacity for municipalities,<ref name=TavaresCamoes /><ref name=BrownPotoski /> and the higher presence of scale economies. Current research shows that municipally owned corporations are frequently more efficient than [[bureaucracy]] but have higher failure rates because of their legal and managerial [[autonomy]].<ref name=Voornetal /> An additional problem is the fact that municipally owned corporations often have more than one municipal owner, and conflict between municipal owners can lead to reduced output for the municipally owned corporation due to various negative spillovers.<ref name="Voornetal18b">{{cite web|url= https://www.researchgate.net/publication/327833751_Background_Autonomy_Steering_and_Corporate_Governance_Determinants_of_the_Effectiveness_of_Governance_of_Municipal_Corporations|title= Background, Autonomy, Steering, and Corporate Governance: Determinants of the Effectiveness of (Governance of) Municipal Corporations|last=Voorn, Bart, Marieke van Genugten, and Sandra van Thiel (2018)|publisher=Lausanne: EGPA}}</ref>
== Background == Under [[New Public Management]], [[corporatization]] became prominent as a step towards (partial) [[privatization]].<ref name="GrossiReichard" /><ref name="Voornetal18">{{cite web|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09540962.2018.1527533|title=Debate: Corporatization as more than a recent crisis-driven development|last=Voorn, Bart, Sandra Van Thiel, and Marieke van Genugten (2018)|publisher=Public Money & Management}}</ref> It soon became an end in itself, aiming to combine government control with efficient, businesslike service delivery that was considered lacking in bureaucratic service delivery. The [[state-owned enterprise]]s that resulted were to be organized akin to private corporations, with the difference that the company's shares remain state ownership are not traded on the [[stock market]].<ref name="Marra">{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Alessandro_Marra2/publication/4732914_Internal_Regulation_by_Mixed_Enterprises_The_Case_of_the_Italian_Water_Sector/links/0deec529a2526c7663000000/Internal-Regulation-by-Mixed-Enterprises-The-Case-of-the-Italian-Water-Sector.pdf|title=Internal regulation by mixed enterprises: the case of the Italian water sector|last=Marra, Alessandro (2007)|publisher=Annals of Public and Cooperative Economics, 78(2): 245-275.}}</ref>
This also became a trend at the local level. Municipal corporation followed a process of [[externalization]] that required new skills and orientations from the respective local governments, and followed common changes in the institutional landscape of [[public services]].<ref name=GrossiReichard>{{cite web|last=Grossi, Giuseppe, and Christoph Reichard (2008)|title=Municipal corporatization in Germany and Italy|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14719030802264275|publisher=Public Management Review, 10(5): 597-617}}</ref> There was a substantial growth in the number of municipally owned corporations in the 1990s and 2000s throughout Europe and the United States.<ref name=Voornetal /><ref name="GrossiReichard" /><ref name="Voornetal18" /><ref name="Ferryetal">{{cite web|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/09540962.2018.1486629|title=New development: Corporatization of local authorities in England in the wake of austerity 2010–2016|last=Ferry, Laurence, Rhys Andrews, Chris Skelcher, and Piotr Wegorowski (2018)|publisher=Public Money & Management}}</ref><ref name="FlorioFecher2011">{{cite web|url=http://econpapers.repec.org/article/blaannpce/v_3a82_3ay_3a2011_3ai_3a4_3ap_3a361-373.htm|title=The future of public enterprises: Contributions to a new discourse|last=Florio, Massimo, and Fabienne Fecher (2011)|publisher=Annals of Public and Cooperative Economics, 82(4): 361-373}}</ref>
== Reasons and effects == Municipal corporatization can be used to improve efficiency of public service delivery (with mixed successes) or as a step towards (partial) privatization or hybridization. Its reasons and effects are somewhat similar as those of [[corporatization]].<ref name=Voornetal18 /><ref name=Ferryetal /><ref name=Tavares>{{cite web|last=António F. Tavares (2017)|title=Ten years after: revisiting the determinants of the adoption of municipal corporations for local service delivery|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/03003930.2017.1356723|publisher=Local Government Studies, 43(5): 697-706.}}</ref>
=== (Potentially) improving efficiency === A key purpose of corporatization is externalization.<ref name="GrossiReichard" /> Such externalization gives the service delivery organization legal and managerial autonomy from politicians, which could potentially increase efficiency, because it safeguards the firm from political exploitation. However, it can also fail to bring efficiency (or cause inefficiency), because this autonomy also reduces the government's ability to monitor its management. Whether corporatization is beneficial may depend on the nature of the service that is corporatized, where autonomy may be less beneficial for more politicized and complex services.<ref name="Voornetal" /> At the local level there may also be higher transaction costs, because contracting capacity may be lower.<ref name=TavaresCamoes /><ref name=BrownPotoski>{{cite web|last=Brown, Trevor, and Matthew Potoski (2003)|title=Transaction Costs and Institutional Explanations for Government Service Production Decisions|url=http://spa.hust.edu.cn/2008/uploadfile/2009-9/20090910194210575.pdf|publisher=Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory}}</ref>
=== Step towards privatization or hybridization === Once a service has been corporatised, it is often relatively easy to (partially) privatise it by selling some or all of the company's shares via the stock market.<ref name="Marra" /> Thus corporatisation can be a stop on the way towards (partial) privatization.<ref name="Marra" /> Corporatization also can be a step towards the creation of [[hybrid organization|hybrid]] forms of organization, such as institutional private-partnerships or inter-municipal service organizations, which are especially relevant at the local level because of opportunities to capture scale economies.<ref name="Voornetal" /><ref name=TavaresCamoes />
=== Alleviating fiscal stress === Municipal corporations tend to be established by local governments experiencing some degree of fiscal stress.<ref name="GrossiReichard" /><ref name="Voornetal18" /><ref name="Ferryetal" /><ref name=Tavares /><ref name=Citroni>{{cite web|last=Citroni, Giulio, Andrea Lippi, and Stefania Profeti (2013)|title=Remapping the State: Inter-Municipal Cooperation through Corporatisation and Public-Private Governance Structures|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/10.1080/03003930.2012.707615|publisher=Local Government Studies, 39(2): 208-234.}}</ref><ref name=Sorensen>{{cite web|last=Sorensen, Rune J. (2007)|title=Does dispersed public ownership impair efficiency? The case of refuse collection in Norway|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.551.5414&rep=rep1&type=pdf|publisher=Public Administration,85(4): 1045-1058.}}</ref> Corporatization was a way to allow local governments to "hide their liabilities by allocating them partly to their companies" or "corporatized their utilities (…) to raise new sources of income from their companies."<ref name="GrossiReichard" />
== Problems with multiple ownership == The frequent ownership of municipally owned corporations by multiple municipalities can cause problems, the so-called 'multiple principal problem', that can lead these to be inefficient<ref name="Voornetal18b" /> or have high failure rates.<ref name="Voornetal" /> There can be free-riding or duplication in steering and monitoring procedures, resulting in high costs. If there is heterogeneity in interests between the multiple municipalities, there may be directive ambiguity or lobbying of the corporations by individual municipalities, leading to high inefficiency. Delegating governance to one elected party may be a way to solve this problem.<ref name="Voornetal18b" />
== Usage == Municipal corporatization is more prominent for some services than for others. It is typically prominent in:<ref name="Voornetal" /><ref name=TavaresCamoes /><ref name="Voornetal18b" /> *Water management *Bus services *Refuse collection *Economy & Housing *Social Affairs & Employment *Education & Culture
== See also == *[[Corporatization]] *[[New Public Management]]
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}

{{About|urban economic zones in China|other uses|New states (disambiguation){{!}}New states}} {{Infobox Chinese|title=New areas|s={{linktext|新区}}|t={{linktext|新區}}|p=xīnqū|l={{nowrap|New Area}}}} {{Administrative levels and divisions of China sidebar}} The '''new areas''' or '''new districts''' of the [[People's Republic of China]] are new urban districts that are given special economic and development support by the [[Central government of the People's Republic of China|central government]] or regional government. New areas are divided into two varieties: administrative or management and further divided into levels: state-level, provincial-level, and prefectural-level. ==State-level new areas== {{Infobox Chinese|title=State-level new areas|s=国家级新区|t=國家級新區|p=Guójiājí Xīnqū|l={{nowrap|national-level new area}}|s2={{nowrap|国家级开放开发新区}}|t2=國家級開放開發新區|p2=Guójiājí Kāifàng Kāifā Xīnqū|l2=national-level open development new area}} The State-level new areas of the [[People's Republic of China]] are special economic-development zones supported by the central government. The zones are parts of cities at various levels in the formal hierarchy but are known as "national-level" or "state-level" in reference to the preferential policies and privileges they are granted directly by the State Council. These privileges are to encourage and attract new developments (particularly [[foreign direct investment]]) to speed up the city's economy.{{cite web|last=Liu|first=Qiang|script-title=zh:副省级新区建设风起：行政区划调整或将解冻？|url=http://finance.ifeng.com/news/region/20110917/4608846.shtml|work= 21st century economic report ({{noitalic|{{lang|zh-hans|21世纪经济报道}}) |publisher=Ifeng Finance |accessdate=8 September 2012}} {|class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%;" |- ! page.title: Poznań University of Economics and Business

revision.text:
{{infobox university |name = Poznań University of Economics and Business<ref name="changename">[http://ue.poznan.pl/en/news,c16/news,c15/university-changed-name-into-poznan-university-of-economics,a42231.html University changed name into Poznań University of Economics and Business]</ref> |native_name = Uniwersytet Ekonomiczny w Poznaniu |native_name_lang = pl |image = Poznań University of Economics and Business.jpg |motto = |established = 1926 |type = Public |image_size = 200 |endowment = |faculty = 722 (2008) |staff = 1141 (2008) |students = 10 159 (2014) <ref name="liczbastudentow">{{cite web | url = http://stat.gov.pl/obszary-tematyczne/edukacja/edukacja/szkoly-wyzsze-i-ich-finanse-w-2014-r-,2,11.html | title = Szkoły wyższe i ich finanse w 2014 r. | publisher = Główny Urząd Statystyczny | pages = 78 | issn = 1506-2163 | language = pl |date=June 2016}}</ref> |rector = Professor [[Maciej Żukowski]] |city =[[Poznań]] |country =[[Poland]] |campus = |free_label = |free = |footnotes = |website =[http://www.ue.poznan.pl www.ue.poznan.pl] |address =al. Niepodległości 10 60-967 Poznań }}
The '''Poznań University of Economics and Business''' is one of the business schools in Poland.
The Poznań University of Economics and Business (PUEB) is an academic institution in the western part of the country attracting students from many parts of Poland. It is the biggest and oldest business university in the region of Wielkopolska.
The main campus of the university is located in Poznań, but the University offers its courses also in seven other locations (colleges of higher education) situated within a distance of 30–100 km from Poznań ([[Bydgoszcz]], [[Kalisz]], [[Konin]], [[Piła]], [[Leszno]], [[Zielona Góra]], [[Szamotuły]]).
== History == The university's origin goes back to 1926, when the Foundation of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry founded the College of Commerce. As a private school, it had no authority to grant degrees. The school was given the authority in 1938 and, in the same year, was named the Academy of Commerce.<ref>http://ue.poznan.pl/en/university,c13/about-pue,c28/pue-history,c42/</ref>
In 1950, there were 2026 students attending the [[Academy]]. In that year, the Academy was taken over by the state and renamed the Higher School of Economics, initially with two faculties, then three. In 1954, the University ran uniform five-year courses leading to a master's degree.
In 1974, the school was named the Academy of Economics and was granted the authority to award the degrees of doctor and [[habilitated]] doctor (both of economic sciences).
In 1990, the Poznań Academy of Economics fundamentally restructured its faculties, courses, specialisations and curricula. While the years 1998-2000 witnessed a further growth in the number of students. Changes in syllabuses make it possible to aim at European educational standards in all major fields of training and specialisation.
On December 27, 2008, the school was formally granted the status of a university and given its current name - University of Economics in Poznań. Starting 1 October 2015 our University changed its name into Poznań University of Economics and Business.<ref name="changename" />
== Offers == Presently, PUEB specialises in educating economists, managers and specialists in quality management in all sectors of the economy. It offers all academic degrees: Master of Arts, Master of Science, Doctorate and Habilitation (mgr, dr, dr hab.) in three study modes (day, evening and extramural). The University expands its post-master programmes in order to meet the growing demand from those who are already professionally active. During the academic year 2000/2001, the University introduced the [[European Credit Transfer System]] (ECTS) at the Faculty of Management, the Faculty of Economics and the Faculty of Commodity Science.
== Students == In the academic year 2014/2015, 10,159 students have enrolled,<ref name="liczbastudentow" /> although, in the academic year 2010/2011, there were altogether app. 15,000 students enrolled.<ref>http://www.ue.poznan.pl/home-international-cooperation-and-exchange/poznan-university-of-economics/</ref>
== International Students == For international students, the University has developed courses in English, French, German and Russian as well as Polish language course for beginners. The courses in foreign languages are also available for Polish students, who are thus given an opportunity to develop their language skills and prepare for studies abroad.
== Research == The main subjects of research range from various aspects of Poland’s economic transformation to the preparation of Polish enterprises for competition within the European Union and the globalization trends in the world economy. Product and organisational innovations are those subjects of research which the Poznań University of Economics intends to develop further in close co-operation with Polish enterprises. PUE also focuses on international market research (primarily the EU, but also Central and East European countries) in order to facilitate the expansion of Poland’s export trade.
== University Ranking == In terms of enrolment as well as scientific and academic potential, the Poznań University of Economics ranks among the leading economic universities in Poland.<ref>http://www.perspektywy.pl/portal/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=916&catid=107&Itemid=244</ref><ref name="polityka.pl">http://www.polityka.pl/nauka/_resource/multimedium/20034495</ref><ref name="ranking.perspektywy.org">http://www.ranking.perspektywy.org/2014/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1:rankingi-2014-tabele&catid=2&Itemid=104&idRanking=50</ref><ref>http://ue.poznan.pl/pl/aktualnosci,c16/aktualnosci,c15/sukces-uep-w-rankingach-eduniversal,a6102.html</ref> Since 2000, the University has become second in rankings published by such Polish magazines as Polityka, Rzeczpospolita, Perspektywy, Magazyn Businessman and Newsweek Polska.<ref name="polityka.pl"/><ref name="ranking.perspektywy.org"/>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{DEFAULTSORT:Poznan University Of Economics}} [[Category:Universities and colleges in Poznań]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1926]] [[Category:1926 establishments in Poland]] [[Category:Business schools in Poland]] [[Category:Universities of economics in Europe]] {{Universities in Poland}} {{authority control}}

{{unref|date=December 2013}} A '''Purchasing Manager''' is an employee within a [[company]], [[business]] or other [[organization]] who is responsible at some level for buying or approving the acquisition of goods and services needed by the company. Responsible for buying the best quality products, goods and services for their company at the most competitive prices, purchasing managers work in a wide range of sectors for many different organizations. The position responsibilities may be the same as that of a [[buyer]] or purchasing agent, or may include wider supervisory or managerial responsibilities. A Purchasing Manager may oversee the acquisition of materials needed for [[Manufacturing|production]], general supplies for offices and facilities, equipment, or construction contracts. A Purchasing Manager often supervises purchasing agents and buyers, but in small companies the Purchasing Manager may also be the purchasing agent or buyer. The '''Purchasing Manager''' position may also carry the title "'''Procurement Manager'''" or in the public sector, "'''Procurement Officer'''". He or she can come from both an Engineering or Economics background.
A Purchasing Manager's responsibilities may include: * seeking reliable [[vendor (supply chain)|vendors]] or suppliers to provide quality goods at reasonable prices * negotiating prices and contracts * reviewing technical specifications for [[raw materials]], components, equipment or buildings * determining quantity and timing of deliveries (more commonly in small companies) * forecasting upcoming demand.
==See also==
* [[Purchasing Managers Index]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Purchasing Manager}} [[Category:Business occupations]] [[Category:Procurement]]

{{Infobox Politician | name = Qasim Sultan Al Banna | image = Qasim_Sultan_Al_Banna.jpg | caption = Director General of Dubai Municipality till 2006 | birth_place = [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | website = www.qasimsultan.com }}
'''Qasim Sultan Al Banna''' has a distinguished career spanning more than 30 years, during which he held various positions in Dubai Municipality, United Arab Emirates. He started his career as Assistant Engineer, he was promoted to Assistant Director of the Technical Sector, and progressed successively to the posts of Deputy Director, Acting Director, and Director General of the Municipality.
As a result of his strong leadership qualities, he has succeeded in transforming Dubai into a highly efficient city. UN-HABITAT has granted the honorary record of the program to Qasim Sultan in 1994. He was selected as the first Goodwill Ambassador of the United Nations Human Settlements Program in the Arab States In 1998.
In addition, other international awards have honoured the high levels of performance in Dubai Municipality. The Municipality has received numerous awards from the Arab Towns Organisation in various fields including environmental protection, preservation of urban heritage represented in historical buildings, as well as the Organisation of Islamic Capitals and Cities, and the Australian award in waste management field, As well as the 1999 Leadership Award awarded to the Dubai Municipality in New York by the World Council for Community Welfare and the Cannes International Prize for Water and Cities granted by the Mediterranean Water Network and UNESCO in 2001.
In addition to his duties as Director General of Dubai Municipality, Qasim Sultan has taken part in numerous activities including the development of policies, the implementation and management of government functions such as membership in the boards of several organisations and unions, as well as active participation in non-governmental activities such as cultural and sports activities such as the presidency of a sports and cultural club in Dubai .
== Local, regional and international tasks he has undertaken ==
* Director General of Dubai Municipality (1993-2006) * Member of the Executive Council of the Emirate of Dubai * Chairman, Board of Director Department of Health and Medical Services (2001-2005) * Member of the Development Board (1994-2000) * Chairman of Development Board (2001-2004) * Member of General Secretariat of the UAE Municipalities (1992-2006) * Member of UAE Federal Environment Authority * Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Dubai International Award for Best Practices in Improving Living Conditions. * Member of the Board of Directors of the UAE Standards and Metrology Authority (1982-2006). * Chairman of the Organizing Committee of the Annual Meetings of the Board of Governors of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank Group 2003. * Member of Administration Council of the Organization of Islamic Capitals and Cities in Saudi Arabia (1992-2006) * Member of the Executive Office of the Organization of Arab Cities * Chairman of the Organization of Arab Cities (1994-1997) * Host and co-chair person of the Dubai International Conference on Best Practices organized by Dubai Municipality and the United Nations Center for Human Settlements (UNCHS) in November 1995. * Member of the United Nations General Advisory Committee, which includes eminent personalities during the Habitat II Conference (June 1996). * Chairman of the closing plenary session of the World Congress of the International Union of Local Authorities (IULA) held in Mauritius in April 1997. * Head of the delegation of the World Council of Cities and Local Authorities to the dialogue session with the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development in New York (April 1997). * He was selected as Goodwill Ambassador of the United Nations Center for Human Settlements in 1998. * Membership in the United Nations Advisory Committee on Local Authorities – UNACLA (2000) * Chairman of the UAE Basketball Association (1996-2000). * First Vice-President of the National Olympic Committee. * Chairman, of [[Al-Ahli Dubai F.C.|Ahli club]] (1974-2006)
== Awards ==
* Habitat Scroll of Honor (1994) * American Business Council, Dubai, Award (1997) * Environment Award (2001) * Alexandria University Award for Regional Leadership (2005) * The Dubai Municipality, under his management, received more than 80 Arab and international awards between 1988 and 2006 from regional and international organizations in various fields of environment, culture, urban heritage, gardens, parks, landscaping and others.
== Cultural Activity == He wrote weekly articles in Al Bayan Newspaper until 2009, currently he is writing articles from time to time on his website www.qasimsultan.com. He has written many books, including The Years of Construction and Transformation, Dubai from A small Village to A global City which was translated into English. He has also published books containing collections of articles he wrote throughout his career on some public and private experiences and his political views.
* THE YEARS OF CONSTRUCTION AND TRANSFORMATION, DUBAI FROM A SMALL VILLAGE TO A GLOBAL CITY * TRAVEL ANECDOTES * STRANGE WORLD: A JOURNEY BEHIND DOORS OF LETTERS * ON THE WINGS OF PAPER * DOORS AND WINDOWS * CONVERSATION OF THE PAPERS * STATIONS IN LIFE AFFAIRS AND ANXIETIES
